turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Pike never confessed.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: We've been making progress, I see.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Running out of time, are we? Tick- tock, tick-tock, how long till your witnesses fly the coop?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Fifty minutes.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Not much time to solve the crime. Tell me, detective, how did it feel taking blood money from Guissepe Torres? Did it weigh on your conscience or did you just not think about it?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Pike never confessed.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: No, but it got you interested, didn't it? Got you to dig. Inspired Ray to tell you terribly sordid tales about drugs and creek beds and dead little sergeants who stuck their noses where they didn't belong.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Dunbar says you were.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Then he's mistaken. You know, I really don't think my father would approve of this line of questioning --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: You and Dunbar got your stories straight. Little details, little inconsistencies, designed to bounce us back from one of you to the other, asking questions, killing time, until the transport arrives and whisks you away to where Senator Daddy can protect you. You think you're just going to slide out of this? You're an accessory to murder, Levi, you're going to jail --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: You can't threaten me --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: It doesn't matter, Levi. We're going to find those bodies and when we do, I'm going to make sure one of them has a bullet in them that matches your weapon --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: It won't work --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: It will and you know why? Because you're not a person anymore, you're a cadet in the United States Army; you have no identity, no Miranda warning, and no rights. So I'm gonna throw you to the wolves, and unlike you, I'm gonna get away with it, because you're pissing me off!

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Enjoy your flight to Washington --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Wait --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: What.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Dunbar's telling the truth.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Wrong answer --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: We did get our stories straight, but not because we killed anyone.  It was because I threatened him.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Who, Levi --

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: Childs.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I told him what had really happened to West. Told him to keep quiet about it or I'd destroy him. Because if it came out that I was involved with the whole PX scam, my father would be finished.

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: I scared Dunbar into silence. He's been trying to cover for me the whole time. We got here, you came to see me... I didn't know if I could trust him with that kind of secret --

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: So you framed him. The same way Childs was going to frame Pike.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: What happened with Nunez?

turns.speaker: KENDALL
turns.text: He came after us. And I told Dunbar he had to kill him...

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Hurricane's due after midnight and we're still going out?

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Toughens us up, Pike. You don't like it, quit.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: What the fuck happened to you --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: What the fuck happened to you? One minute you're next to me and the next you're gone and the sky lights up like fucking Christmas --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Whoever shot the Sarge blew a grenade first --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Blame the nigger, then, huh? Someone turns up dead, you just look for the darkest face in the crowd --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Thank God...

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: What the fuck are you doing?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: This place is going, Mueller. We gotta move --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Shut the fuck up.  He was gonna cut him loose.

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: We all know what you did, Pike. I don't know what kind of nigger voodoo you been working in here, but --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Where's your shirt, Mueller?

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: I used it to start the fire --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Still got mine on, not a speck of blood on it. Not a bad trick for a murderer -- you said you burned yours?

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Goddammit, Ray, we gotta get out of here --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: We're not going anywhere.

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Cadet Michael Mueller, I hereby place you under military arrest for the murder of Sergeant Nathan West --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: The fuck are you talking about --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: You are to be stripped of all weapons and placed under guard --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Bullshit --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: Until we return to base, and ballistics can match your weapon to the slugs in Sergeant West's body --

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: MUELLER
turns.text: Tell him to shut up --

turns.speaker: PIKE
turns.text: -- failure to comply with this arrest is a court martialable offense in and of itself --

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Sign here and here.  Hey, ain't you the folks workin' on that whole hulabaloo from last night?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Terrible tragedy. One of those Section Eight boys worked in here. Pike. Heard he got out okay.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Funny. I swear I saw them bring him and the smaller guy in this morning.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: No, no that was Cadet Dunbar --

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: You mean Ray Dunbar? Well, that ain't right.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Ma'am, Ray Dunbar's black.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: This is totally unnecessary --

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: He asked to see a policeman, we're getting him a policeman.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: But this guy you called, he's not even Army --

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: He's former Army and the best I've ever seen in a room. Besides, he knows the territory, we did Basic together here.  You've had three hours with Dunbar and haven't gotten a peep, we need to take a different tack.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: He's not Army, it's not official --

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: Then it's unofficial.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: Search parties for the others are fanning out in a ten click radius from the pickup. If they're hurt and we can get to them in time...

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: I called the JAG Corps, the two cadets we retrieved are to be flown to D.C. on a transport leaving here at 1700 --

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: You think he did it?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: No --

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: It's too neat.

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: You want Kendall, don't you?

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: He tried to burn Dunbar to us. You don't do that if you're not involved.

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: You both know if you do this, if you go after a Senator's son and you're wrong... it's not just me in the hot seat anymore.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: We know.

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: I'm giving you a chance to walk away.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: What happens to Dunbar now?

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: Gets on his plane in ten minutes, which means you two are done. You'll understand if I don't walk you out.

turns.speaker: OSBORNE
turns.text: You never told me why you got kicked out of...

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: The army kicked you out for drugs...

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: You motherfuckers have just made the worst mistake of your lives! You have chosen to join my Army! This Army is my mother, my father, and my little virgin sister and I will not allow anyone or anything that is not up to my standards near her pretty little virgin cooze, do you understand me -- give me a sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: THE CADETS
turns.text: Sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: Those who I deem unworthy to pass through this camp will quit, and those who refuse to quit I will kill. You ever hear of a training accident -- give me a sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: THE CADETS
turns.text: Sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: In my time I have killed sixteen men for the good of my country, sixteen men whose entrance into this Army I could not condone, as it would weaken the fabric of this nation's defense! This base suffers an average of three training accidents a year, unfortunate incidents that I will not hesitate to repeat if you cross me, understand -- give me a sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: THE CADETS
turns.text: Sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: So forget what you've seen on Sixty fucking Minutes about the kinder, gentler military -- you will either succeed, quit, or die by my hand!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: Some of you may have heard there's a hurricane coming! American soldiers do not wait for good weather -- they do not wait for a bright sunshiney day to do their duty! An American Soldier learns to operate in the worst conditions and turn said conditions into an advantage against their enemy! Anyone who thinks these conditions are too harsh, feel free to lay down and die, you get me?

turns.speaker: THE CADETS
turns.text: Sir, yes, sir!

turns.speaker: WEST
turns.text: LZ is two clicks North of a cabin, you are to split into teams of two and work your way through your designated area blasting as many targets as you can find! Each area has twenty targets, first team to take all twenty and find the cabin wins! Teams are as follows -- Dunbar and Nunez, Pike and Mueller, Kendall and Childs!

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Great, great. That's fantastic.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It was on that night Karl met his destiny. And I met mine. Almost.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Hey kid! Your friend just made himself a star.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: That's great.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: See! The big guy likes it.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I just saw the woman I'm going to marry, I know it. But then I lost her.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Tough break. Most men have to get married before they lose their wives.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I'm going to spend the rest of my life looking for her. That or die alone.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Jesus, kid.  Let me guess. Real pretty, blonde hair, blue hat?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: I know her uncle. Friends of the family.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Who is she? Where does she live?

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Kid. Don't waste your time. She's out of your league.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: What do you mean? You don't even know me.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Sure I do. You were hot shit back in Hickville, but here in the real world, you got squat. You don't have a plan. You don't have a job. You don't have anything but the clothes on your back.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I've got a whole backpack full of clothes!

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Someone stole my backpack.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Kid, you were a big fish in a small pond. This here is the ocean, and you're drowning. Take my advice and go back to Puddleville. You'll be happy there.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I don't have a job, but I would have a job if you gave me one. And I may not have much, but I have more determination than any man you're ever going to meet.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Sorry, kid. I don't do charity.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I'll work night and day, and you won't have to pay me. You just have to tell me who she is.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Didn't kill anything, did I?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: A few rabbits, but I think one of them was already dead.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: That would explain the indigestion.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: I was wrong about you kid. You may not have much, but what you got, you got a lot of. You could get any girl.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: There's only one I want.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Her name is Sandra Templeton. She's going to Auburn. The semester's almost over, so you better hurry.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: AMOS
turns.text: Good luck, kid.

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: Welcome to ya. What's your name?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Edward Bloom.

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: Bloom like a flower?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: Oh. Here! Right here. Edward Bloom. We weren't expecting you yet.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You were expecting me?

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: What is this place?

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: The town of Spectre. Best kept secret in Alabama. Says here you're from Ashton, right? Last person we had from Ashton was Norther Winslow.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: The poet? What ever happened to him?

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: He's still here. Let me buy you a drink. I'll tell you all about it. Hell, I'll have him tell you.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: No. I've gotta meet somebody. I'm already running late.

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: Now tell me if that isn't the best pie you ever ate.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It truly is.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I have to leave. Tonight.

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: This town is everything a man could ask for. And if I were to end up here, I'd consider myself lucky. But the fact is, I'm not ready to end up anywhere.

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: No one's ever left.

turns.speaker: BEAMEN
turns.text: You won't find a better place!

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I don't expect to.

turns.speaker: DON PRICE
turns.text: Or are you too scared?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I'll go in right now and get that eye.

turns.speaker: DON PRICE
turns.text: Then do it.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Fine, I will.

turns.speaker: DON PRICE
turns.text: Fine, you do it.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Fine, I'm doing it.

turns.speaker: DON PRICE
turns.text: You get the eye?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I brought it.

turns.speaker: DON PRICE
turns.text: Let's see it.

turns.speaker: DON PRICE
turns.text: Bloom!

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Don.

turns.speaker: DON PRICE
turns.text: What the hell are you doing? This is my girl. Mine!

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I didn't know she belonged to anybody.

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Will.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Dr. Bennett. It's good to see you.  My wife, Josephine.

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: A pleasure.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Can I see him?

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Absolutely. Be good for you to talk to him.

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Glad to see you're not trying to have a heartfelt talk. It's one of my greatest annoyances, when people talk to those who can't hear them.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: My father and I have an advantage. We never talk.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How long have you known my father?

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Thirty years. Maybe more.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: How would you describe him?

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Five-eleven. One-eighty. Regulated hypertension.  How would his son describe him?

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Did your father ever tell you about the day you were born?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: A thousand times. He caught an uncatchable fish.

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Not that one. The real story. Did he ever tell you that?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. BENNETT
turns.text: Your mother came in about three in the afternoon. Her neighbor drove her, on account of your father was on business in Wichita. You were born a week early, but there were no complications. It was a perfect delivery. Now, your father was sorry to miss it, but it wasn't the custom for the men to be in the room for deliveries then, so I can't see as it would have been much different had he been there. And that's the real story of how you were born.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Did you see that woman?

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: What did she look like?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Well, she... uh...

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: Was she nekkid?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: It's not a woman, it's a fish. No one ever catches her.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Eighteen.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: I'm eight. That means when I'm eighteen, you'll be 28. And when I'm 28, you'll only be 38.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You're pretty good at arithmetic.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: And when I'm 38, you'll be 48. And that's not much difference at all.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: How are you gonna make it without your shoes?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I suspect it will hurt a lot.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: Promise me you'll come back.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I promise. Someday. When I'm really supposed to.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: You must be Edward Bloom.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: How did you know?

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: No one would come out here unless they had business. And no one would have business with me except for you. You're buying the town.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Apparently I've overlooked this one piece of it, and I'd like to remedy that. You see, in order for the town to be preserved, the trust must own it in its entirety.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: So I've heard.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I'll offer you more than it's worth. And you know you won't have to move. Nothing will change except the name on the deed, you have my word.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: In so many words, yes.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: Then I don't think so Mr. Bloom. If nothing is going to change, I'd just as soon it not change in the way it hasn't been changing all this time.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It's not like you're going to lose anything. You can ask anyone in town. I've been nothing if not generous. I want the best for everyone.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Helping people makes me happy.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: I'm not convinced you should be happy.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I'm sorry. Have I offended you?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You're Beamen's daughter. Your last name is different.  You married.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: I was 18. He was 28. Turns out that was a big difference.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: I won't be selling you this house, Mr. Bloom.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I see. I thank you for your time.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: It's okay, just leave it.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I can get it. I can just...

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Lord, I'm sorry I...

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: Please. Go. Just go.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I'll...

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: Go.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Don't. Don't be embarrassed. I should never have let you think that...  I am in love with my wife.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: And from the moment I saw her until the moment I die, she's the only one.

turns.speaker: JENNY
turns.text: Lucky girl.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I'm sorry, Jenny. I am.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You're lucky to get four words out of them in English. But if you were to walk through the jungle, you'd hear them speaking the most elaborate French. Those parrots talk about everything: politics, movies, fashion -- everything but religion.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Hi. How are you feeling?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I was dreaming.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: What were you dreaming about?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Means when you dream about something that's going to happen.  Like one night, I had a dream where this crow came and told me, "Your Aunt is going to die." I was so scared I woke up my parents. They told me it was just a dream, to go back to bed. But the next morning, my Aunt Stacy was dead.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: That's terrible.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Terrible for her, but think about me, young boy with that kind of power. Wasn't three weeks later that the crow came back to me in a dream and said, "Your Grampa is going to die." Well, I ran right back to my parents. My father said, no, Gramps is fine, but I could see there was trepidation. And true enough, that next morning my Grampa was dead.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Because see, my mother was banging the milkman.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: No, I understand.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: He was slipping her a little extra cream.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: He was buttering her rolls. Pumping her churn. Splashing milk in her box.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Stop.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: They were squeezing the cheese. Clanking the bottles. Licking the popsicle.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Spooning the sherbet.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Can I take your picture?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You don't need a picture. Just look up handsome in the dictionary.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Please?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: That's because we didn't have a wedding. Your mother-in-law was never supposed to marry me. She was engaged to somebody else.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: I never knew.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Will never told you that?  Probably just as well. He would have told it all wrong anyway. All the facts and none of the flavor.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh, so this is a tall tale?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Well, it's not a short one.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: I thought you said you didn't have a church wedding.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Well, we were all set to, but there was a complication.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Is it the medicine that's making you thirsty?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Truth is, I've been thirsty my whole life. Never really known why.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: There was one time when I was eleven...

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: You were talking about your wedding.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I didn't forget. I was just working on a tangent. See, most men, they'll tell a story straight through, and it won't be complicated, but it won't be interesting either.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: I like your stories.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: And I like you.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Hardly two stories in the whole place. Now I've heard in real cities, they've got buildings so tall you can't even see the tops of 'em.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Wouldn't lie to you. And they've got all-you-can-eat buffets. You can eat a lot, can't you?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: I can.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: So why are you wasting your time in a small town? You're a big man. You should be in the big city.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You're just trying to get me to leave, aren't you? That's why they sent you here.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: What's your name, Giant?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Karl.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Mine's Edward. And truthfully, I do want you to leave, Karl. But I want to leave with you.  You think this town is too small for you, well, it's too small for a man of my ambition. I can't see staying here a day longer.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You don't like it?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I love every square inch of it. But I can feel the edges closing in on me. A man's life can only grow to a certain size in a place like this.  So what do you say? Join me?

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: What did she say?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Beats me.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You know anyone's who's taken it?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: That poet, Norther Winslow did. He was going to Paris, France. He must have liked it, because no one ever heard from him again.  Tell you what. You take the other way and I'll cut through here. Meet you on the far side.

turns.speaker: KARL
turns.text: You're not trying to run away?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Just to be sure, you can take my pack.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You can see my predicament. My wedding ring, the symbol of fidelity to my wife, soon to be the mother of my child, was now lost in the gut of an uncatchable fish.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Make him stop.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: What, a father's not allowed to talk about his son?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I am a footnote in that story. I am the context for your great adventure. Which never happened! Incidentally! You were selling novelty products in Wichita the day I was born.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Jesus Christ.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Friend of yours? Did you help him out of a bind?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Come on, Will. Everyone likes that story.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No Dad, they don't. I do not like the story. Not anymore, not after a thousand times. I know all the punchlines, Dad. I can tell them as well as you can.  For one night, one night in your entire life, the universe does not revolve around Edward Bloom. It revolves around me and my wife. How can you not understand that?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: The one about the witch.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Your mom says I can't tell you that one anymore. You get nightmares.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'm not scared.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You --  -- are in for a surprise.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Am I?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Having a kid changes everything. I mean, there's the diapers and the burping and the midnight feedings...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Did you do any of that?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: No, but I hear it's terrible. Then you spend years trying to corrupt and mislead this child, fill its head with nonsense and still it turns out perfectly fine.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You think I'm up for it?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You learned from the best.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: People needn't worry so much. It's not my time yet. This isn't how I go.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Truly. I saw it in The Eye.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: The Old Lady by the swamp.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: She was a witch.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: No, she was old and probably senile. Maybe schizophrenic.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I saw my death in that eye. And this is not how it happens.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: So how does it happen?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Surprise ending. Wouldn't want to ruin it for you.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: There was this panhandler who used to stop me every morning when I came out of this coffee shop near the office.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: And every day I gave him a quarter. Every day. Then I got sick and was out for a couple of weeks. And when I went back there, you know what he said?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You owe me three-fifty.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: True story.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: When did you ever work in an office?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: There's a lot you don't know about me.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: You're right.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Dad, I'm hoping we can talk about some things while I'm here.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You mean, while I'm here.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I'd just like to know the true versions of things. Events. Stories. You.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Your mother hasn't been keeping up the pool. If you wanted to you could...

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You know where the chemicals are?

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I used to do it when you were gone, remember? I used to do it a lot.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: I thought you weren't dying.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I said this isn't how I go. The last part is much more unusual. Trust me on that.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Why not religion, Dad?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It's rude to talk about religion. You never know who you're going to offend.

turns.speaker: WILL
turns.text: Josephine actually went to the Congo last year.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Oh, so you know.
